content.webTitle: Gabby Logan: ‘This World Cup’s a triumph. Even my builder’s thrilled’

fields.headline: Gabby Logan: ‘This World Cup’s a triumph. Even my builder’s thrilled’
fields.bodyText: Gabby Logan knew things would be different for this World Cup when her builder started discussing the matches with her, play by play. Unlike some of the responses she had the last time around, he didn’t qualify his remarks by saying the performances were “good … for women’s football” or question the quality of the games. “He was just thrilled by it and enjoying the tournament,” she says. “And that’s the thing, it’s the same game, with the same goalposts – I don’t know where the debate came about that the goals were smaller – and you can get into it quickly. You’re not introducing audiences to an entirely new sport, it’s not chairball. It’s football! When they watch it, they realise..” Logan is enjoying a triumphant run anchoring the BBC’s coverage of the Fifa World Cup in France as its trusted voice and experience on the ground. It’s her sixth World Cup but the first in which the women’s game has been treated with anywhere near the seriousness afforded the men’s; the BBC has committed to showing every game, of the tournament across its channels and the red button, with care made to show viewers back stories for the participating teams. “It’s a tanker to turn and it takes time … but it was about a year ago that [the BBC] said they wanted to broadcast every match. It normalises the game; it was never going to be tokenistic.” Deftly negotiating tapas at her local in Beaconsfield, Logan is as poised and polished as she is on screen. “They weren’t going to put these matches on for small audiences,” she explains. “You can’t put something on without any knowledge that there’s an appetite for it, and the audience have pleasantly surprised us – they’ve been bigger than we hoped.” England’s win over Scotland set a record in the UK for women’s football, with 6 million viewers; this is expected to climb for the team’s much-anticipated last-16 game against Cameroon today. Logan is warm but has a no-nonsense efficiency; by her own admission, she can be brusque, gets frustrated by tardiness and slackness and lightly eye-rolls men on Twitter who see fit to comment on what she’s wearing on TV. “I just think, ‘Ugh, you can’t take on all that’. I don’t feel I’ve ever traded on looks in my career. [But] I do think it’s important [presenters] appear on screen looking like we dressed properly; you want to feel groomed but not distracting and it’s about respect – I turn up in your living room.” When she came up in the 90s, working first at Sky Sports and later at ITV, Logan felt less at ease negotiating the sexism that came with the job. “I was fortunate to have worked at the right time, the universe was ready to see women talk about sport … looking back, there were hard things because, of course, people said things that were unacceptable and of course they did things that were unacceptable.” She pauses but won’t elaborate. “But the thing I found hard was retaining my sense of being a woman and trying not to morph into [the men] to get on.” At the height of ladette culture, Logan says she was frequently offered men’s magazines covers and felt anxious about not taking that route or “being pretty enough to be a broadcaster” but was determined to ride it out. “I remember consciously thinking to myself, ‘This phase will pass and I have to stay true to myself’. I wasn’t interested in drinking 10 pints and being in that world. I liked being a woman and I l liked sport; I just had to wait until that was acceptable.” Now, she says, she is content. Her twins, Lois and Reuben, are almost 14 and she and her husband, the former Scottish rugby union player Kenny Logan, spend much of their weekends ferrying their children around to compete in sports. “I said to my husband recently that we should have had another baby and he laughed and asked how we’d divide even more of our time between them.” Logan is one of four siblings; her younger brother died when she was 19 and he was 15. She talks openly about the strain her family suffered With her own children, she’s determined to make the most of their time together as a unit “before they move out and leave” and is chief organiser of family time. Mostly, she hopes she and Kenny have instilled “a strong work ethic” in them both. “My kids are funny, they’ll turn around and ask: ‘Are you sure we don’t have trust funds?’ And I’ll say: ‘Yep, I’m positive yes, where have you heard this form?’. Who talks about trust funds?!”. Logan is all about hard graft: since 2007, she has been a key element of the BBC’s presenting team, deputising for Gary Lineker on Match of the Day and anchoring the athletics and rugby coverage. This month, Amazon Prime announced it had won the rights to show 20 Premier League matches in the coming season and will be assembling a new presenting team; could she be tempted by an offer? “You’ve got to feel valued,” she says diplomatically, “and realise market forces are at play but I’m doing jobs I love and my opinions are taken seriously and I have an influence on the people I work with; I’ve done the hours.”
